column31: Bad practices: 1) Do not write your own tool for configuration management (use TypeSafe Config, Hashicorp Vault, Spring Clound Config, e.t.c)2) Do not rely on default values everywhere (like if thread pool is not specified in the config I'll use 10)3) Do not store passwords and other sensitive parts of configuration in VCSGood practices:1) Write tests for your configuration, i.e. simulate different environments and validate that all properties are set, e.t.c.2) Make configuration convenient so developers would easily maintain it and add new properties. Configurable code can save you from a patch release and make life easier3) Add a way to troubleshoot configuration issues on running servers, for example expose a REST service which will return configuration value by their keys. Think of masking sensitive data and securing it in production

column30: The biggest problem is making the application as unbreakable as possible. Often times configuration files are a great place where a user can break the program. A solution to this is to have extensive bounds checking for configuration options, and storing a default and known-working configuration file inside the application, so that if values are missing, they can be replaced with the defaults. Some error output, letting the user know that they messed something up in the configuration file is helpful as well. Sometimes I've gone so far as to point out exactly where (down to the very character) a configuration error was found.
column31: Good practice 1: don't be afraid to have more than one configuration file. It can help keep things organized. Good practice 2: document your options well. Good practice 3: be prepared for user errors. Bad practice 1: use a non-human readable format for storing options. Bad practice 2: use a domain specific language for configuration (unless you have a really good reason to, don't make your user learn another language just to config your application). Bad practice 3: silently fail or give an ambiguous error message about the bad configuration. The more details the user can be given, the better.

column30: We were designing our web application that we wanted to be fully configurable. Its core is basically a set of small pieces (widgets) that introduce different UI elements or functionality, but you need to manually put those pieces together by creating an XML file that described how all those small pieces were structured on the front-end - that was basically one huge configuration file. Quite soon it became pretty obvious that those configuration files will grow immensely in size making them really hard to maintain. Also we often had to reuse some existing configuration parts across different front-end configuration files. So we created a way to include them within each other. Since XML wasn't accessed directly and was read into object form in runtime - I've written a quite complex merge algorithm that can merge all kinds of objects which also supported merging all those includes together to provide us the final configuration in runtime while keeping it simple in the original form.
column31: Good practices:1. Structure your configuration options from the start, probably split them by responsibility/modules/plugins/etc - whatever fit your project the best2. Make each configuration option responsible for one single thing, do not reuse the same option for different cases unless it is reasonable in the application context3. Make sure to name your options properly from the start and ensure all your developers folow one naming convention across all your projects, that will save you a lot of timeBad practices:1. Do not use multiple ways of configuring your application - you don't want to end up having some settings within property files, some settings placed in XML and some being read from database2. Do not introduce configuration options unless they are actually required, in most cases extra configurations might create unnecessary complications which otherwise could be avoided3. Do not create multiple options that have the same role - it is not likely to happen in a small/new project but it could be the case in big projects, try to keep all your configurations in check

column30: The most important problem is knowing what options our users want and how to tailor those options to that audience. Often times we can't communicate with all of our users and that creates a very big gap of understanding between developers and our userbase.  We have to guess what our users want and the issue with that is that we have an audience that is comprised of very different people who have different needs and who have very different goals. We have to account for users of our software as well as developers that build addons to it. This is even more complicated in the case of our project because we have to even consider people who aren't directly using or developing for our platform because Glowkit is a fork of an actively used project. We can't really solve this issue but we can lessen its effects by determining use cases and finding configuration options that could be created to help that use case.
column31: I think that every configuration option you have should be supported by a use case. Even if you don't have planning, if you can't think of a valid use case that the configuration option will help that can't be helped more by another solution, don't add it. Next, have good defaults. Know that a lot of your users will not change options and all of them will expect your software to work well with the defaults. Finally, make sure you document your options. This is extremely important. You are making these options for your users and your users are not going out of their way to find out what an option does.As for bad practices, don't make a config option for everything. You may be tempted to solve every user issue with another option, but sometimes you have to decide on some major part of your code that you will have to have a concrete flow or design for. Second, do not change configuration options too much. If your config options change rapidly, you are just making it harder for the users of your config. Third, don't have confusing names internally or user-facing. This just confuses everyone involved.

column30: The systems I work with (Android and iOS mobile apps) have configuration APIs that are fairly easy to work with.  The major problem with configurations is deciding which elements should be open to configuration and which should be options should be decided by the developer to be non-configurable.  I try to keep configuration options to a minimum.  Many users never configure the program, and so choosing the best possible defaults for configuration options is important.
column31: Make sure the configuration API (whatever is used) is well understood.  Make sure default configuration is correct for initial installation of the program.  Make sure adding and deleting configuration options are handled gracefully with program updates.  Make sure configurations can be reconstructed if the configuration storage (database or file) is corrupted or deleted.  Understand what configuration options are important to the enduser and which will never be used.  Maybe the user will never want to change a font, or a text color.  Don't add too many configuration options.  The ones you add should be important and options that at least a significant number of your users will want to change.  If there is an option that the user will change very frequently, add it as a menu item and not as a configuration option.  Finally, just because something can be configured doesn't mean it should be.  Programmers are poor judges of this, because we like to tinker with everything.  Users just want to get their work done without trying to understand obscure configuration options.

column31: Good practices:- Command-line flags work really well, there's usually no need for complex data formats to store these. This eases deployment into production, because all configuration information is visible on the command-line and it also allows developers to quickly flip certain flags.- Use "feature flags" to activate / deactivate new code or select between code branches at runtime.- Use configuration options to "canary" a change in code behavior in a new release. As an example, you can deploy a new software version and only enable a new experimental code path for 1% of users at first to get some feedback.Bad practices:- Not documenting configuration options.- Not having a good naming scheme for configuration options.- Having multiple ways to configure a software (e.g. some stuff has to be configured in an XML file, others on the command-line, others in a database).

column31: I'm not expert, but here are my 2 cents:Good:* Centralize configuration.* Create configuration options that reflect user choices, not technical choices. Boolean options (e.g. "deny.unauthenticated.access=true" instead of "spring.AccessFilter=BasicFilter\nbasic.filter.auth.paths=*") tend to work quite well.* A central config file with all default options and comments ("little tutorials") for each option are great.Bad:* Configuring different modules with different options (e.g. leveraging Tomcat, Spring, Hibernate config files tend to be confusing and require a lot of previous knowledge). Configuration is for users (which may include admins) and they do not have to understand all the tricky concepts inside your app.* Config documentation that sits far away from the config itself (e.g. in a wiki) tends to get stale and not consulted.* there is a middle ground between too much and too few configuration options. I cannot pinpoint it but it is good to pay attention: make it sure a new config option brings value.

column30: Dead options collect forever in config files and everyone is afraid to touch them. No one knows if or where they are used, the default value, etc.We wrote a new config framework at requires declaring every option with explicit data types, validation, descriptions and defaults.On startup, it loads all config options and prints their name, description, default and current value.Any unknown property is an error. This prevents making a typo and thinking you configured something (typically an important option needed for production to work). column30: I have bad experience with "configuration bloat" which means that sometimes there is a plethora of config option and you don't really need 99% for almost all usecases. In effect this means someone getting acquainted with the software will miss important config options because most of them can be safely ignored. I try to separate "important" options from the other "detail config" by giving specific examples on how to use the important ones in the top-level documentation.Also I've often faced the issue "do I create two separate programs or do I just add options to one program?". In most cases, separating the program (or at least a clearly separated "sub-command" in the program) is a good solution.
column31: Good:1) Make config option docs immediately accessible - everywhere you can set the option. Also provide FULL value checking. e.g. DO NOT accept negative values where only positive values make sense.2) Clearly mark development/debugging option so the user doesnt confuse them with options he doesnt care about.3) Whatever you can automatically infer from data: Dont have it as a config option. Avoid configuration bloat (too many options which are never used).Bad:1) Require the user to write a complex config file in some arcane format (just add some default config file).2) Ignore how the user will use your application. If you have distinct usecases, just provide distinct example configs. Dont make the user hate you because he has to deal with tons of config options he doesnt really care about.3) Make configs too interdependent or too redundant. In the optimal case, provide just one way to use your program for some specific application, and avoid "if --xyz is set, then --foo must not be set but --bar must be set" things as far as possible. If it is unavoidable (it is sometimes!), try to auto-calculate sensible values from the other args and warn the user visibly that default value X has been used for parameter Y, and provide clear warnings when a dependency is not met ("You set --xyz, but you did not set --bar. Try using --bar 5.1 as a starting point).

Sometimes people complain about JSON as a config format because they quote numbers, quote booleans, etc. but in general I still see JSON as a good config format. I also think that one way that config needs to be extended even further is with "dynamic configs" via callback functions or similar. Currently our system will "Eval" strings, but this is dangerous, and therefore, systems like extending objects via mixins that are specified in plugins should be used, however, this is significantly more complicated than just telling a user to store callback as a string in config.
column31: Good1) Adding configuration should be dead-simple, and accessing configuration options should also be simple. With JSON, a simple "config blob" can be passed to different parts of application easily.2) Make documentation easy to understand, and target the "power user" in your documentation, and make it easy for people to quickly become power users.3) Create plugin systems for things that are too complicated for configBad1) People often do not allow for enough config (especially for complex webapp components), and this makes it so that people have to maintain forks of the entire source tree of some system. Maintaining forks is very hard so I think adding as much config as possible to deter forking is good2) If it is too complicated to configure something, or it requires a rebuild, or something like this, it becomes very hard to iterate quickly. Make it lightweight and text based.3) Introduce sensible defaults, your app should not fail if a config is done wrong, or a config value is missing!
